comments.body:
Thank you for the fix!
Last time I tried this, pybind11.get_include() did not return the correct path inside docker environment. Can you try dome of docker builds, too?

To avoid installing pybind beforehand official example suggests importing pybind11 inside a function get_pybind_include(). Maybe you can add pybind11.get_include() there, too
https://github.com/pybind/python_example/blob/master/setup.py
yes, I will try the docker build. Do you have any readme about how to do the docker builds?

Try this build command
```
make BASE_IMAGE=ubuntu:18.04 PYTHON=python3 TENSORFLOW_TARGET=native docker-build
```

It seem build successfully:
```
creating build/bdist.linux-x86_64/wheel/tflite_runtime-2.1.0.dist-info/WHEEL
creating '/tensorflow/tensorflow/lite/tools/pip_package/gen/tflite_pip/python3/dist/tflite_runtime-2.1.0-cp36-cp36m-linux_x86_64.whl' and adding '.' to it
adding 'tflite_runtime/__init__.py'
adding 'tflite_runtime/_pywrap_tensorflow_interpreter_wrapper.so'
adding 'tflite_runtime/interpreter.py'
adding 'tflite_runtime-2.1.0.dist-info/DESCRIPTION.rst'
adding 'tflite_runtime-2.1.0.dist-info/metadata.json'
adding 'tflite_runtime-2.1.0.dist-info/top_level.txt'
adding 'tflite_runtime-2.1.0.dist-info/WHEEL'
adding 'tflite_runtime-2.1.0.dist-info/METADATA'
adding 'tflite_runtime-2.1.0.dist-info/RECORD'
+ [[ n != \y ]]
+ exit 0
```

Currently python3 will install pybind11 2.5.0. I don't know if it relates with pybind11 version.
@teijeong Can you please take a look on the above comment from @Leslie-Fang. Thanks!
